mn56:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
mn56:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
mn56:1.2.comm: Pāvārika means “blanket-weaver”. Places were often named for their primary economic activity. Probably there was a community of blanket weavers and the park was owned by their leading merchant.

mn56:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto nāḷandāyaṃ paṭivasati mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ.
mn56:2.1.eng: At that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan was residing at Nāḷandā together with a large assembly of Jain ascetics.
mn56:2.1.comm: Jain tradition holds that Mahāvīra passed at a Pāvā near Nāḷandā. Buddhist texts know only the Pāvā of the Mallians to the north. Evidently there has been some confusion, and perhaps “Pāvārika’s mango grove”, the site of discussions with Jains here and at SN 42.8, is the Pāvā known to the Jains. Note, however, that the earliest Jain source for Mahāvīra’s passing, the Kalpasutra, does not say where Pāvā is. But it does say the events were commemorated by the rulers of Kāsī and Kosala, and the Mallians and the Licchavīs. The absence of Magadha and the presence of Malla sit better with the location of Pāvā in Malla rather than Magadha.

mn56:2.2.pli: Atha kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nāḷandāyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena pāvārikambavanaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn56:2.2.eng: Then the Jain ascetic Dīgha Tapassī wandered for alms in Nāḷandā. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to Pāvārika’s mango grove. There he approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
mn56:2.2.comm: In Sanskrit, Dīrghatapasvin was a common name, or rather epithet, for ascetics, meaning “long fervor” in honor of lengthy dedication to practices such as starvation. It is presumably the Dīgha Tapassī of this sutta who is inscribed in a Buddhist stupa at Bharhut teaching a group of students. At least one of his students appears to be holding a small stick, which may be a pictorial representation of the subject of this discourse.

mn56:2.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn56:2.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side. The Buddha said to him,

mn56:2.4.pli: “saṃvijjanti kho, tapassi, āsanāni; sace ākaṅkhasi nisīdā”ti.
mn56:2.4.eng: “There are seats, Tapassī. Please sit if you wish.”

mn56:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn56:3.1.eng: When he said this, Dīgha Tapassī took a low seat and sat to one side.

mn56:3.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

mn56:3.3.pli: “kati pana, tapassi, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto kammāni paññapeti pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
mn56:3.3.eng: “Tapassī, how many kinds of deed does the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan describe for performing bad deeds?”

mn56:3.4.pli: “Na kho, āvuso gotama, āciṇṇaṃ nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa ‘kammaṃ, kamman’ti paññapetuṃ;
mn56:3.4.eng: “Reverend Gotama, the Jain Ñātika doesn’t usually speak in terms of ‘deeds’.

mn56:3.5.pli: ‘daṇḍaṃ, daṇḍan’ti kho, āvuso gotama, āciṇṇaṃ nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa paññapetun”ti.
mn56:3.5.eng: He usually speaks in terms of ‘rods’.”
mn56:3.5.comm: The term “rod” implies violence and punishment unlike the more neutral “deed”. This usage is found in such Jain texts as Uttarādhyayanasūtra 8.10. It was evidently common enough that it could be referred to obliquely as the “three rods” (20.60; see too Isibhāsiyāiṁ 25.2, 35.0.6). It is also found in Mahābhārata 12.228.034c.

mn56:3.6.pli: “Kati pana, tapassi, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto daṇḍāni paññapeti pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
mn56:3.6.eng: “Then how many kinds of rod does the Jain Ñātika describe for performing bad deeds?”

mn56:3.7.pli: “Tīṇi kho, āvuso gotama, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto daṇḍāni paññapeti pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyāti, seyyathidaṃ—
mn56:3.7.eng: “The Jain Ñātika describes three kinds of rod for performing bad deeds:

mn56:3.8.eng: the physical rod, the verbal rod, and the mental rod.”

mn56:3.9.pli: “Kiṃ pana, tapassi, aññadeva kāyadaṇḍaṃ, aññaṃ vacīdaṇḍaṃ, aññaṃ manodaṇḍan”ti?
mn56:3.9.eng: “But are these kinds of rod all distinct from each other?”

mn56:3.10.pli: “Aññadeva, āvuso gotama, kāyadaṇḍaṃ, aññaṃ vacīdaṇḍaṃ, aññaṃ manodaṇḍan”ti.

mn56:3.11.pli: “Imesaṃ pana, tapassi, tiṇṇaṃ daṇḍānaṃ evaṃ paṭivibhattānaṃ evaṃ paṭivisiṭṭhānaṃ katamaṃ daṇḍaṃ nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto mahāsāvajjataraṃ paññapeti pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, yadi vā kāyadaṇḍaṃ, yadi vā vacīdaṇḍaṃ, yadi vā manodaṇḍan”ti?
mn56:3.11.eng: “Of the three rods thus analyzed and differentiated, which rod does the Jain Ñātika describe as being the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds: the physical rod, the verbal rod, or the mental rod?”

mn56:3.12.pli: “Imesaṃ kho, āvuso gotama, tiṇṇaṃ daṇḍānaṃ evaṃ paṭivibhattānaṃ evaṃ paṭivisiṭṭhānaṃ kāyadaṇḍaṃ nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto mahāsāvajjataraṃ paññapeti pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍaṃ, no tathā manodaṇḍan”ti.
mn56:3.12.eng: “The Jain Ñātika describes the physical rod as being the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”
mn56:3.12.comm: In Jainism, all three “rods” create karma, which in Jainism is a kind of subtle matter (pudgala) that adheres to and obscures the soul ( Tattvārthasūtra 6.1–2). Thus all karma is material. Nonetheless, according to Dr. Hiralal Jain, Jainism in Buddhist Literature, the Jain position is not that physical actions are more important, since all three kinds of action must be intentional. Rather, it is that intentional actions performed through the body have a greater weight than those performed by speech or by thought alone. Karma in the Jain system is the result of such intentional action, which clings to the soul as a form of matter.

mn56:3.13.eng: “Do you say the physical rod, Tapassī?”

mn56:3.14.eng: “I say the physical rod, Reverend Gotama.”

mn56:3.15.eng: “Do you say the physical rod, Tapassī?”

mn56:3.16.eng: “I say the physical rod, Reverend Gotama.”

mn56:3.17.eng: “Do you say the physical rod, Tapassī?”

mn56:3.18.eng: “I say the physical rod, Reverend Gotama.”

mn56:3.19.pli: Itiha bhagavā dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ yāvatatiyakaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi.
mn56:3.19.eng: Thus the Buddha made Dīgha Tapassī stand by this point up to the third time.

mn56:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:4.1.eng: When this was said, Dīgha Tapassī said to the Buddha,

mn56:4.2.pli: “tvaṃ panāvuso gotama, kati daṇḍāni paññapesi pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
mn56:4.2.eng: “But Reverend Gotama, how many kinds of rod do you describe for performing bad deeds?”

mn56:4.3.pli: “Na kho, tapassi, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatassa ‘daṇḍaṃ, daṇḍan’ti paññapetuṃ;
mn56:4.3.eng: “Tapassī, the Realized One doesn’t usually speak in terms of ‘rods’.

mn56:4.4.pli: ‘kammaṃ, kamman’ti kho, tapassi, āciṇṇaṃ tathāgatassa paññapetun”ti?
mn56:4.4.eng: He usually speaks in terms of ‘deeds’.”
mn56:4.4.comm: The terms daṇḍa (“rod” or “punishment”) and kamma (“deed”) are synonymous in Jainism. The three daṇḍas of body, speech, and mind are also found in Manusmṛti 12.8.

mn56:4.5.pli: “Tvaṃ panāvuso gotama, kati kammāni paññapesi pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā”ti?
mn56:4.5.eng: “Then how many kinds of deed do you describe for performing bad deeds?”

mn56:4.6.pli: “Tīṇi kho ahaṃ, tapassi, kammāni paññapemi pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, seyyathidaṃ—
mn56:4.6.eng: “I describe three kinds of deed for performing bad deeds:

mn56:4.7.eng: physical deeds, verbal deeds, and mental deeds.”

mn56:4.8.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso gotama, aññadeva kāyakammaṃ, aññaṃ vacīkammaṃ, aññaṃ manokamman”ti?
mn56:4.8.eng: “But are these kinds of deed all distinct from each other?”

mn56:4.9.pli: “Aññadeva, tapassi, kāyakammaṃ, aññaṃ vacīkammaṃ, aññaṃ manokamman”ti.

mn56:4.10.pli: “Imesaṃ panāvuso gotama, tiṇṇaṃ kammānaṃ evaṃ paṭivibhattānaṃ evaṃ paṭivisiṭṭhānaṃ katamaṃ kammaṃ mahāsāvajjataraṃ paññapesi pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, yadi vā kāyakammaṃ, yadi vā vacīkammaṃ, yadi vā manokamman”ti?
mn56:4.10.eng: “Of the three deeds thus analyzed and differentiated, which deed do you describe as being the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds: physical deeds, verbal deeds, or mental deeds?”

mn56:4.11.pli: “Imesaṃ kho ahaṃ, tapassi, tiṇṇaṃ kammānaṃ evaṃ paṭivibhattānaṃ evaṃ paṭivisiṭṭhānaṃ manokammaṃ mahāsāvajjataraṃ paññapemi pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā kāyakammaṃ, no tathā vacīkamman”ti.
mn56:4.11.eng: “I describe mental deeds as being the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much physical deeds or verbal deeds.”

mn56:4.12.eng: “Do you say mental deeds, Reverend Gotama?”

mn56:4.14.eng: “Do you say mental deeds, Reverend Gotama?”

mn56:4.16.eng: “Do you say mental deeds, Reverend Gotama?”

mn56:4.18.pli: Itiha dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho bhagavantaṃ imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ yāvatatiyakaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami.
mn56:4.18.eng: Thus the Jain ascetic Dīgha Tapassī made the Buddha stand by this point up to the third time, after which he got up from his seat and went to see the Jain Ñātika.

mn56:5.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto mahatiyā gihiparisāya saddhiṃ nisinno hoti bālakiniyā parisāya upālipamukhāya.
mn56:5.1.eng: Now at that time the Jain Ñātika was sitting together with a large assembly of Bālaki laypeople headed by Upāli.
mn56:5.1.comm: Bālaki is obscure. The commentary says it could mean either “foolish” (which seems harsh) or “from the village of the child salt miners” (which is obscure and distant, MN 128:7.1). A Dṛpta Bālāki of the Gārgya clan features in Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.1, so perhaps it was a proper name (from balāka, “crane”).

mn56:5.2.pli: Addasā kho nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ;
mn56:5.2.eng: The Jain Ñātika saw Dīgha Tapassī coming off in the distance

mn56:5.4.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, tapassi, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
mn56:5.4.eng: “So, Tapassī, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

mn56:5.5.pli: “Ito hi kho ahaṃ, bhante, āgacchāmi samaṇassa gotamassa santikā”ti.
mn56:5.5.eng: “Just now, sir, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”

mn56:5.6.pli: “Ahu pana te, tapassi, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn56:5.6.eng: “But did you have some discussion with him?”

mn56:5.7.pli: “Ahu kho me, bhante, samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.

mn56:5.8.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana te, tapassi, ahu samaṇena gotamena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn56:5.8.eng: “And what kind of discussion did you have with him?”

mn56:5.9.pli: Atha kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho yāvatako ahosi bhagavatā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa ārocesi.
mn56:5.9.eng: Then Dīgha Tapassī informed the Jain Ñātika of all they had discussed.

mn56:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:6.1.eng: When he had spoken, the Jain Ñātika said to him,

mn56:6.3.pli: Yathā taṃ sutavatā sāvakena sammadeva satthusāsanaṃ ājānantena evameva dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena samaṇassa gotamassa byākataṃ.
mn56:6.3.eng: Dīgha Tapassī has answered the ascetic Gotama like a learned disciple who rightly understands their teacher’s instructions.

mn56:6.4.pli: Kiñhi sobhati chavo manodaṇḍo imassa evaṃ oḷārikassa kāyadaṇḍassa upanidhāya.
mn56:6.4.eng: For how impressive is the measly mental rod when compared with the solid physical rod?

mn56:6.5.pli: Atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo”ti.
mn56:6.5.eng: Rather, the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”

mn56:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, upāli gahapati nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:7.1.eng: When he said this, the householder Upāli said to him,

mn56:7.3.pli: Yathā taṃ sutavatā sāvakena sammadeva satthusāsanaṃ ājānantena evamevaṃ bhadantena tapassinā samaṇassa gotamassa byākataṃ.
mn56:7.3.eng: The Honorable Tapassī has answered the ascetic Gotama like a learned disciple who rightly understands their teacher’s instructions.

mn56:7.4.pli: Kiñhi sobhati chavo manodaṇḍo imassa evaṃ oḷārikassa kāyadaṇḍassa upanidhāya.
mn56:7.4.eng: For how significant is the measly mental rod when compared with the solid physical rod?

mn56:7.5.pli: Atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo.
mn56:7.5.eng: Rather, the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.

mn56:7.6.pli: Handa cāhaṃ, bhante, gacchāmi samaṇassa gotamassa imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ vādaṃ āropessāmi.
mn56:7.6.eng: I’d better go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine regarding this point.

mn56:7.7.pli: Sace me samaṇo gotamo tathā patiṭṭhahissati yathā bhadantena tapassinā patiṭṭhāpitaṃ; seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso dīghalomikaṃ eḷakaṃ lomesu gahetvā ākaḍḍheyya parikaḍḍheyya samparikaḍḍheyya; evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ ākaḍḍhissāmi parikaḍḍhissāmi samparikaḍḍhissāmi.
mn56:7.7.eng: If he stands by the position that he stated to Dīgha Tapassī, I’ll take him on in debate and drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong man would grab a fleecy sheep and drag it to and fro and round about!

mn56:7.8.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma balavā soṇḍikākammakāro mahantaṃ soṇḍikākilañjaṃ gambhīre udakarahade pakkhipitvā kaṇṇe gahetvā ākaḍḍheyya parikaḍḍheyya samparikaḍḍheyya; evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ ākaḍḍhissāmi parikaḍḍhissāmi samparikaḍḍhissāmi.
mn56:7.8.eng: Taking him on in debate, I’ll drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong brewer’s worker would toss a large brewer’s sieve into a deep lake, grab it by the corners, and drag it to and fro and round about!

mn56:7.9.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma balavā soṇḍikādhutto vālaṃ kaṇṇe gahetvā odhuneyya niddhuneyya nipphoṭeyya; evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ vādena vādaṃ odhunissāmi niddhunissāmi nipphoṭessāmi.
mn56:7.9.eng: Taking him on in debate, I’ll shake him down and about and give him a beating, like a strong brewer’s mixer would grab a strainer by the corners and shake it down and about, and give it a beating!

mn56:7.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kuñjaro saṭṭhihāyano gambhīraṃ pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā sāṇadhovikaṃ nāma kīḷitajātaṃ kīḷati; evamevāhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ sāṇadhovikaṃ maññe kīḷitajātaṃ kīḷissāmi.
mn56:7.10.eng: I’ll play a game of hemp-washing with the ascetic Gotama, like a sixty-year-old elephant would plunge into a deep lotus pond and play a game of hemp-washing!

mn56:7.11.pli: Handa cāhaṃ, bhante, gacchāmi samaṇassa gotamassa imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ vādaṃ āropessāmī”ti.
mn56:7.11.eng: Sir, I’d better go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine on this point.”

mn56:7.12.pli: “Gaccha tvaṃ, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ vādaṃ āropehi.
mn56:7.12.eng: “Go, householder, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine on this point.

mn56:7.13.pli: Ahaṃ vā hi, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyyaṃ, dīghatapassī vā nigaṇṭho, tvaṃ vā”ti.
mn56:7.13.eng: For either I should do so, or Dīgha Tapassī, or you.”
mn56:7.13.comm: It is rather a shame that neither in Buddhist nor Jain tradition is there a record of the two actually meeting.

mn56:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:8.1.eng: When he said this, Dīgha Tapassī said to the Jain Ñātika,

mn56:8.2.pli: “na kho metaṃ, bhante, ruccati yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyya.
mn56:8.2.eng: “Sir, I don’t believe it’s a good idea for the householder Upāli to rebut the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.

mn56:8.3.pli: Samaṇo hi, bhante, gotamo māyāvī āvaṭṭaniṃ māyaṃ jānāti yāya aññatitthiyānaṃ sāvake āvaṭṭetī”ti.
mn56:8.3.eng: For the ascetic Gotama is deceitful. He knows a conversion trick, and uses it to convert the disciples of other religions.”
mn56:8.3.comm: It's tempting to translate āvaṭṭaniṁ māyaṁ as “conversion magic”, but māyā doesn’t seem to have the sense of literal magic in the Suttas. Rather, the Buddha is accused of some kind of trick or con.

mn56:8.4.pli: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, tapassi, anavakāso yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:8.4.eng: “It is impossible, Tapassī, it cannot happen that Upāli could become Gotama’s disciple.
mn56:8.4.comm: This is a setup intended to satirize Mahāvīra’s claims to omniscience.

mn56:8.5.pli: Ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ samaṇo gotamo upālissa gahapatissa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:8.5.eng: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.

mn56:8.6.pli: Gaccha tvaṃ, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ vādaṃ āropehi.
mn56:8.6.eng: Go, householder, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine on this point.

mn56:8.7.pli: Ahaṃ vā hi, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyyaṃ, dīghatapassī vā nigaṇṭho, tvaṃ vā”ti.
mn56:8.7.eng: For either I should do so, or Dīgha Tapassī, or you.”

mn56:9.2.pli: tatiyampi kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:9.2.eng: and a third time, Dīgha Tapassī said to the Jain Ñātika,

mn56:9.3.pli: “na kho metaṃ, bhante, ruccati yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyya.
mn56:9.3.eng: “Sir, I don’t believe it’s a good idea for the householder Upāli to rebut the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.

mn56:9.4.pli: Samaṇo hi, bhante, gotamo māyāvī āvaṭṭaniṃ māyaṃ jānāti yāya aññatitthiyānaṃ sāvake āvaṭṭetī”ti.
mn56:9.4.eng: For the ascetic Gotama is deceitful. He knows a conversion trick, and uses it to convert the disciples of other religions.”

mn56:9.5.pli: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, tapassi, anavakāso yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:9.5.eng: “It is impossible, Tapassī, it cannot happen that Upāli could become Gotama’s disciple.

mn56:9.6.pli: Ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ samaṇo gotamo upālissa gahapatissa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:9.6.eng: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.

mn56:9.7.pli: Gaccha tvaṃ, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa imasmiṃ kathāvatthusmiṃ vādaṃ āropehi.
mn56:9.7.eng: Go, householder, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine on this point.

mn56:9.8.pli: Ahaṃ vā hi, gahapati, samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyyaṃ, dīghatapassī vā nigaṇṭho, tvaṃ vā”ti.
mn56:9.8.eng: For either I should do so, or Dīgha Tapassī, or you.”

mn56:9.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho upāli gahapati nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena pāvārikambavanaṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho upāli gahapati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:9.9.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the householder Upāli to the Jain Ñātika. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn56:9.10.eng: “Sir, did the Jain ascetic Dīgha Tapassī come here?”

mn56:9.12.pli: “Ahu kho pana te, bhante, dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn56:9.12.eng: “But did you have some discussion with him?”

mn56:9.13.pli: “Ahu kho me, gahapati, dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.

mn56:9.14.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana te, bhante, ahu dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena saddhiṃ kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn56:9.14.eng: “And what kind of discussion did you have with him?”
mn56:9.14.comm: Upāli makes sure to hear the Buddha’s side before proceeding.

mn56:9.15.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yāvatako ahosi dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ upālissa gahapatissa ārocesi.
mn56:9.15.eng: Then the Buddha informed Upāli of all they had discussed.

mn56:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, upāli gahapati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:10.1.eng: When he said this, the householder Upāli said to him,

mn56:10.3.pli: Yathā taṃ sutavatā sāvakena sammadeva satthusāsanaṃ ājānantena evamevaṃ dīghatapassinā nigaṇṭhena bhagavato byākataṃ.
mn56:10.3.eng: The Jain ascetic Tapassī has answered the ascetic Gotama like a learned disciple who rightly understands their teacher’s instructions.

mn56:10.4.pli: Kiñhi sobhati chavo manodaṇḍo imassa evaṃ oḷārikassa kāyadaṇḍassa upanidhāya?
mn56:10.4.eng: For how significant is the measly mental rod when compared with the solid physical rod?

mn56:10.5.pli: Atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo”ti.
mn56:10.5.eng: Rather, the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”

mn56:10.6.pli: “Sace kho tvaṃ, gahapati, sacce patiṭṭhāya manteyyāsi siyā no ettha kathāsallāpo”ti.
mn56:10.6.eng: “Householder, so long as you debate on the basis of truth, we can have some discussion about this.”

mn56:10.7.eng: “I will debate on the basis of truth, sir.

mn56:10.8.eng: Let us have some discussion about this.”

mn56:11.2.pli: idhassa nigaṇṭho ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno sītodakapaṭikkhitto uṇhodakapaṭisevī.
mn56:11.2.eng: Take a Jain ascetic who is sick, suffering, gravely ill. They turn down cold water and use only hot water.
mn56:11.2.comm: Jain ascetics could not use cold water on account of the living creatures therein. Ācāraṅgasūtra 2.2.1.8 says a nigaṇṭha must not stay at a lay person’s house because they may fall ill and be treated with, among other things, cold water (see also 2.6.2.2 and 2.1.7.7). Uttarādhyayanasūtra 1.1.3.7 dismisses the Buddhist claim that mere filtering is sufficient to render water allowable (see also 2.4).

mn56:11.3.eng: Not getting cold water, they might die.

mn56:11.4.pli: Imassa pana, gahapati, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto katthūpapattiṃ paññapetī”ti?
mn56:11.4.eng: Now, where does the Jain Ñātika say they would be reborn?”

mn56:11.5.pli: “Atthi, bhante, manosattā nāma devā tattha so upapajjati”.
mn56:11.5.eng: “Sir, there are gods called ‘mind-bound’. They would be reborn there.

mn56:11.7.eng: Because they died with mental attachment.”
mn56:11.7.comm: It is not clear from the text why they must have attachment.

mn56:11.8.pli: “Manasi karohi, gahapati, manasi karitvā kho, gahapati, byākarohi.
mn56:11.8.eng: “Think about it, householder! You should think before answering.

mn56:11.9.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn56:11.9.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn56:11.10.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te, gahapati, esā vācā:
mn56:11.10.eng: But you said that you would debate on the basis of truth.”

mn56:11.13.pli: “Kiñcāpi, bhante, bhagavā evamāha, atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo”ti.
mn56:11.13.eng: “Even though the Buddha says this, still the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”

mn56:12.2.pli: idhassa nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto sabbavārivārito sabbavāriyutto sabbavāridhuto sabbavāriphuṭo.
mn56:12.2.eng: Take a Jain ascetic who is restrained in all that is to be restrained, is bridled in all that is to be restrained, has shaken off evil in all that is to be restrained, and is curbed in all that is to be restrained.
mn56:12.2.comm: MS has nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto, but I follow PTS nigaṇṭho, in line with the pattern in this sutta and with the parallel at DN 2:29.4. | At Isibhāsiyāiṁ 29.19, Vardhamāna ( Mahāvīra) teaches that a sage is savva-vārīhiṁ vārie, “restrained in all restraints”, which clearly parallels our current passage. In that passage, “restraint” refers to stopping the influx of defilements through the five senses, neither delighting in the pleasant nor loathing the unpleasant. | Read vāri as future passive participle (cf. Sanskrit vārya). | Dhuta in the sense “shaken off (evil by means of ascetic practices)” is a characteristic Jain term. | For sabbavāriphuṭo compare ophuṭo at MN 99:15.5. In both cases phuṭ appears in a string of terms from the root var, and is possibly a corrupted form, or at least has the same meaning.

mn56:12.3.pli: So abhikkamanto paṭikkamanto bahū khuddake pāṇe saṅghātaṃ āpādeti.
mn56:12.3.eng: When going out and coming back they injure many little creatures.
mn56:12.3.comm: Jain ascetics use a soft broom to sweep the path before them to avoid this.

mn56:12.4.pli: Imassa pana, gahapati, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto kaṃ vipākaṃ paññapetī”ti?
mn56:12.4.eng: Now, what result does the Jain Ñātika say they would incur?”

mn56:12.5.pli: “Asañcetanikaṃ, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto no mahāsāvajjaṃ paññapetī”ti.
mn56:12.5.eng: “Sir, the Jain Ñātika says that unintentional acts are not very blameworthy.”

mn56:12.8.pli: “Cetanaṃ pana, gahapati, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto kismiṃ paññapetī”ti?
mn56:12.8.eng: “But where does the Jain Ñātika say that intention is classified?”

mn56:12.10.pli: “Manasi karohi, gahapati, manasi karitvā kho, gahapati, byākarohi.
mn56:12.10.eng: “Think about it, householder! You should think before answering.

mn56:12.11.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn56:12.11.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn56:12.12.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te, gahapati, esā vācā:
mn56:12.12.eng: But you said that you would debate on the basis of truth.”

mn56:12.15.pli: “Kiñcāpi, bhante, bhagavā evamāha, atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo”ti.
mn56:12.15.eng: “Even though the Buddha says this, still the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”

mn56:13.2.pli: ayaṃ nāḷandā iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ākiṇṇamanussā”ti?
mn56:13.2.eng: Is this Nāḷandā successful and prosperous, populous, full of people?”

mn56:13.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante, ayaṃ nāḷandā iddhā ceva phītā ca bahujanā ākiṇṇamanussā”ti.

mn56:13.5.eng: Suppose a man were to come along with a drawn sword

mn56:13.7.pli: ‘ahaṃ yāvatikā imissā nāḷandāya pāṇā te ekena khaṇena ekena muhuttena ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ karissāmī’ti.
mn56:13.7.eng: ‘In one hour I will reduce all the living creatures within the bounds of Nāḷandā to one heap and mass of flesh!’

mn56:13.9.pli: pahoti nu kho so puriso yāvatikā imissā nāḷandāya pāṇā te ekena khaṇena ekena muhuttena ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kātun”ti?

mn56:13.10.pli: “Dasapi, bhante, purisā, vīsampi, bhante, purisā, tiṃsampi, bhante, purisā, cattārīsampi, bhante, purisā, paññāsampi, bhante, purisā nappahonti yāvatikā imissā nāḷandāya pāṇā te ekena khaṇena ekena muhuttena ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kātuṃ.
mn56:13.10.eng: “Sir, even ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty men couldn’t do that.

mn56:13.11.eng: How significant is one measly man?”

mn56:13.13.pli: idha āgaccheyya samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā iddhimā cetovasippatto.
mn56:13.13.eng: Suppose an ascetic or brahmin with psychic power, who has achieved mastery of the mind, were to come along

mn56:13.15.pli: ‘ahaṃ imaṃ nāḷandaṃ ekena manopadosena bhasmaṃ karissāmī’ti.
mn56:13.15.eng: ‘I will reduce Nāḷandā to ashes with a single malevolent act of will!’

mn56:13.17.pli: pahoti nu kho so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā iddhimā cetovasippatto imaṃ nāḷandaṃ ekena manopadosena bhasmaṃ kātun”ti?

mn56:13.18.pli: “Dasapi, bhante, nāḷandā, vīsampi nāḷandā, tiṃsampi nāḷandā, cattārīsampi nāḷandā, paññāsampi nāḷandā pahoti so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā iddhimā cetovasippatto ekena manopadosena bhasmaṃ kātuṃ.
mn56:13.18.eng: “Sir, an ascetic or brahmin with psychic power, who has achieved mastery of the mind, could reduce ten, twenty, thirty, forty, or fifty Nāḷandās to ashes with a single malevolent act of will.

mn56:13.19.eng: How significant is one measly Nāḷandā?”

mn56:13.20.pli: “Manasi karohi, gahapati, manasi karitvā kho, gahapati, byākarohi.
mn56:13.20.eng: “Think about it, householder! You should think before answering.

mn56:13.21.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn56:13.21.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn56:13.22.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te, gahapati, esā vācā:
mn56:13.22.eng: But you said that you would debate on the basis of truth.”

mn56:13.25.pli: “Kiñcāpi, bhante, bhagavā evamāha, atha kho kāyadaṇḍova mahāsāvajjataro pāpassa kammassa kiriyāya pāpassa kammassa pavattiyā, no tathā vacīdaṇḍo, no tathā manodaṇḍo”ti.
mn56:13.25.eng: “Even though the Buddha says this, still the physical rod is the most blameworthy for performing bad deeds, not so much the verbal rod or the mental rod.”

mn56:13.27.pli: sutaṃ te daṇḍakīraññaṃ kāliṅgāraññaṃ majjhāraññaṃ mātaṅgāraññaṃ araññaṃ araññabhūtan”ti?
mn56:13.27.eng: Have you heard how the wildernesses of Daṇḍaka, Kaliṅga, Mejjha, and Mātaṅga came to be that way?”
mn56:13.27.comm: This passage is referenced at Mil 5.1.6:16.3. | Daṇḍaka was a vast wilderness covering much of the Deccan; it features heavily in the Rāmāyaṇa. Vettam Mani’s Puranic Encyclopedia informs us that Daṇḍa was a son of Ikṣvāku, founder of the solar dynasty, who gave Daṇḍa the country between the mountains Himālaya and Vindhya. But Daṇḍa raped Arā, the daughter of the hermit Śukra. Śukra destroyed the country of Daṇḍa in a rain of fire. See too Vālmīki Rāmāyaṇa 3.5. Buddhist accounts may be found in the Sarabhaṅga Jātaka at Ja 522 and Mahāvastu 99. This sage is possibly noted by name at MN 116:6.13. | Kaliṅga was a coastal realm in modern Odisha and Andhra Pradesh. Its downfall is related in Ja 522, although that was a kammic result of vile sin against ascetics rather than by psychic power. | Mejjha’s destruction is told in Ja 497. There, Mātaṅga features as a wise sage, and it is not clear to me how this relates to the wilderness of that name. In the suttas, the person Mātaṅga was regarded as an enlightened sage of the past (MN 116:6.17, Snp 1.7:26.1).

mn56:13.28.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante, sutaṃ me daṇḍakīraññaṃ kāliṅgāraññaṃ majjhāraññaṃ mātaṅgāraññaṃ araññaṃ araññabhūtan”ti.

mn56:14.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, gahapati, kinti te sutaṃ kena taṃ daṇḍakīraññaṃ kāliṅgāraññaṃ majjhāraññaṃ mātaṅgāraññaṃ araññaṃ araññabhūtan”ti?

mn56:14.2.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, isīnaṃ manopadosena taṃ daṇḍakīraññaṃ kāliṅgāraññaṃ majjhāraññaṃ mātaṅgāraññaṃ araññaṃ araññabhūtan”ti.
mn56:14.2.eng: “I heard that it was because of a malevolent act of will by seers that the wildernesses of Daṇḍaka, Kaliṅga, Mejjha, and Mātaṅga came to be that way.”

mn56:14.3.pli: “Manasi karohi, gahapati, manasi karitvā kho, gahapati, byākarohi.
mn56:14.3.eng: “Think about it, householder! You should think before answering.

mn56:14.4.pli: Na kho te sandhiyati purimena vā pacchimaṃ, pacchimena vā purimaṃ.
mn56:14.4.eng: What you said before and what you said after don’t match up.

mn56:14.5.pli: Bhāsitā kho pana te, gahapati, esā vācā:
mn56:14.5.eng: But you said that you would debate on the basis of truth.”

mn56:15.1.eng: “Sir, I was already delighted and satisfied by the Buddha’s very first simile.

mn56:15.2.pli: Api cāhaṃ imāni bhagavato vicitrāni pañhapaṭibhānāni sotukāmo, evāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ paccanīkaṃ kātabbaṃ amaññissaṃ.
mn56:15.2.eng: Nevertheless, I wanted to hear the Buddha’s various solutions to the problem, so I thought I’d oppose you in this way.

mn56:15.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn56:15.4.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn56:15.5.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn56:15.5.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn56:15.6.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn56:15.6.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

mn56:16.1.pli: “Anuviccakāraṃ kho, gahapati, karohi, anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī”ti.
mn56:16.1.eng: “Householder, you should act after careful consideration. It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to act after careful consideration.”

mn56:16.2.pli: “Imināpāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato bhiyyoso mattāya attamano abhiraddho yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha: ‘anuviccakāraṃ kho, gahapati, karohi, anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī’ti.
mn56:16.2.eng: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the Buddha, since he tells me to act after careful consideration.

mn56:16.3.pli: Mañhi, bhante, aññatitthiyā sāvakaṃ labhitvā kevalakappaṃ nāḷandaṃ paṭākaṃ parihareyyuṃ:
mn56:16.3.eng: For if the followers of other religions were to gain me as a disciple, they’d carry a banner all over Nāḷandā, saying:

mn56:16.4.eng: ‘The householder Upāli has become our disciple!’

mn56:16.5.pli: Atha ca pana maṃ bhagavā evamāha:

mn56:16.6.pli: ‘anuviccakāraṃ kho, gahapati, karohi, anuviccakāro tumhādisānaṃ ñātamanussānaṃ sādhu hotī’ti.
mn56:16.6.eng: ‘Householder, you should act after careful consideration. It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to act after careful consideration.’

mn56:16.7.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, dutiyampi bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn56:16.7.eng: For a second time, I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn56:16.8.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn56:16.8.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

mn56:17.1.pli: “Dīgharattaṃ kho te, gahapati, nigaṇṭhānaṃ opānabhūtaṃ kulaṃ yena nesaṃ upagatānaṃ piṇḍakaṃ dātabbaṃ maññeyyāsī”ti.
mn56:17.1.eng: “For a long time now, householder, your family has been a well-spring of support for the Jain ascetics. You should consider giving to them when they come.”

mn56:17.2.pli: “Imināpāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato bhiyyoso mattāya attamano abhiraddho yaṃ maṃ bhagavā evamāha: ‘dīgharattaṃ kho te, gahapati, nigaṇṭhānaṃ opānabhūtaṃ kulaṃ yena nesaṃ upagatānaṃ piṇḍakaṃ dātabbaṃ maññeyyāsī’ti.
mn56:17.2.eng: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the Buddha, since he tells me to consider giving to the Jain ascetics when they come.

mn56:17.3.pli: Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, samaṇo gotamo evamāha:
mn56:17.3.eng: I have heard, sir, that the ascetic Gotama says this:

mn56:17.4.eng: ‘Gifts should only be given to me, not to others.
mn56:17.4.comm: The same calumny is reported at AN 8.12:27.6 and AN 3.57:1.4.

mn56:17.5.pli: mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dānaṃ dātabbaṃ;
mn56:17.5.eng: Gifts should only be given to my disciples, not to the disciples of others.

mn56:17.6.pli: mayhameva dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ;
mn56:17.6.eng: Only what is given to me is very fruitful, not what is given to others.

mn56:17.7.pli: mayhameva sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalaṃ, nāññesaṃ sāvakānaṃ dinnaṃ mahapphalan’ti.
mn56:17.7.eng: Only what is given to my disciples is very fruitful, not what is given to the disciples of others.’

mn56:17.8.pli: Atha ca pana maṃ bhagavā nigaṇṭhesupi dāne samādapeti.
mn56:17.8.eng: Yet the Buddha encourages me to give to the Jain ascetics.

mn56:17.9.pli: Api ca, bhante, mayamettha kālaṃ jānissāma.
mn56:17.9.eng: Well, sir, we’ll know the proper time for that.

mn56:17.10.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, tatiyampi bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn56:17.10.eng: For a third time, I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn56:17.11.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn56:17.11.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

mn56:18.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā upālissa gahapatissa anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi, seyyathidaṃ—
mn56:18.1.eng: Then the Buddha taught the householder Upāli step by step, with

mn56:18.2.pli: dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ, kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṅkilesaṃ, nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi.
mn56:18.2.eng: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.

mn56:18.3.pli: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi upāliṃ gahapatiṃ kallacittaṃ muducittaṃ vinīvaraṇacittaṃ udaggacittaṃ pasannacittaṃ, atha yā buddhānaṃ sāmukkaṃsikā dhammadesanā taṃ pakāsesi—
mn56:18.3.eng: And when he knew that Upāli’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:

mn56:18.4.eng: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

mn56:18.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṃ vatthaṃ apagatakāḷakaṃ sammadeva rajanaṃ paṭiggaṇheyya;
mn56:18.5.eng: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,

mn56:18.6.pli: evameva upālissa gahapatissa tasmiṃyeva āsane virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
mn56:18.6.eng: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in Upāli:

mn56:18.7.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

mn56:18.8.pli: Atha kho upāli gahapati diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:18.8.eng: Then Upāli saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions.

mn56:18.9.pli: “handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bhante, gacchāma, bahukiccā mayaṃ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
mn56:18.9.eng: He said to the Buddha, “Well, now, sir, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn56:19.1.pli: Atha kho upāli gahapati bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena sakaṃ nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā dovārikaṃ āmantesi:
mn56:19.1.eng: And then the householder Upāli approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went back to his own home, where he addressed the gatekeeper,

mn56:19.2.pli: “ajjatagge, samma dovārika, āvarāmi dvāraṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ nigaṇṭhīnaṃ, anāvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ bhagavato bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
mn56:19.2.eng: “My good gatekeeper, from this day forth close the gate to Jain monks and nuns, and open it for the Buddha’s monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

mn56:19.3.pli: Sace koci nigaṇṭho āgacchati tamenaṃ tvaṃ evaṃ vadeyyāsi:
mn56:19.3.eng: If any Jain ascetics come, say this to them:

mn56:19.4.comm: This is even harsher than it appears, for one of the Jains’ rules is not to wait when invited for food (natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, eg. MN 12:45.1).

mn56:19.5.pli: Ajjatagge upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato.
mn56:19.5.eng: From now on the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.

mn56:19.6.pli: Āvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ nigaṇṭhīnaṃ, anāvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ bhagavato bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
mn56:19.6.eng: His gate is closed to Jain monks and nuns, and opened for the Buddha’s monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

mn56:19.7.pli: Sace te, bhante, piṇḍakena attho, ettheva tiṭṭha, ettheva te āharissantī’”ti.
mn56:19.7.eng: If you require almsfood, wait here, they will bring it to you.’”

mn56:19.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho dovāriko upālissa gahapatissa paccassosi.

mn56:20.2.pli: “upāli kira gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato”ti.
mn56:20.2.eng: Upāli had become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.

mn56:20.3.pli: Atha kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:20.3.eng: He went to the Jain Ñātika and said to him,

mn56:20.4.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, upāli kira gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato”ti.
mn56:20.4.eng: “Sir, they say that the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.”

mn56:20.5.pli: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, tapassi, anavakāso yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:20.5.eng: “It is impossible, Tapassī, it cannot happen that Upāli could become Gotama’s disciple.

mn56:20.6.pli: Ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ samaṇo gotamo upālissa gahapatissa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyyā”ti.
mn56:20.6.eng: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.”

mn56:20.8.pli: tatiyampi kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:20.8.eng: and a third time, Dīgha Tapassī said to the Jain Ñātika,

mn56:20.9.eng: “Sir, they say that the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.”

mn56:20.10.eng: “It is impossible, Tapassī, it cannot happen that Upāli could become Gotama’s disciple.

mn56:20.11.eng: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.”

mn56:20.12.pli: “Handāhaṃ, bhante, gacchāmi yāva jānāmi yadi vā upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato yadi vā no”ti.
mn56:20.12.eng: “Well, sir, I’d better go and find out whether or not Upāli has become Gotama’s disciple.”

mn56:20.13.pli: “Gaccha tvaṃ, tapassi, jānāhi yadi vā upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato yadi vā no”ti.
mn56:20.13.eng: “Go, Tapassī, and find out whether or not Upāli has become Gotama’s disciple.”

mn56:21.1.pli: Atha kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho yena upālissa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
mn56:21.1.eng: Then Dīgha Tapassī went to Upāli’s home.

mn56:21.2.pli: Addasā kho dovāriko dīghatapassiṃ nigaṇṭhaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn56:21.2.eng: The gatekeeper saw him coming off in the distance

mn56:21.5.pli: Ajjatagge upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato.
mn56:21.5.eng: From now on the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.

mn56:21.6.pli: Āvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ nigaṇṭhīnaṃ, anāvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ bhagavato bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
mn56:21.6.eng: His gate is closed to Jain monks and nuns, and opened for the Buddha’s monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

mn56:21.7.pli: Sace te, bhante, piṇḍakena attho, ettheva tiṭṭha, ettheva te āharissantī”ti.
mn56:21.7.eng: If you require almsfood, wait here, they will bring it to you.”

mn56:21.8.pli: “Na me, āvuso, piṇḍakena attho”ti vatvā tato paṭinivattitvā yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:21.8.eng: Saying, “No, worthy man, I do not require almsfood,” he turned back and went to the Jain Ñātika and said to him,

mn56:21.9.pli: “saccaṃyeva kho, bhante, yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato.
mn56:21.9.eng: “Sir, it’s really true that Upāli has become Gotama’s disciple.

mn56:21.10.pli: Etaṃ kho te ahaṃ, bhante, nālatthaṃ, na kho me, bhante, ruccati yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropeyya.
mn56:21.10.eng: Sir, I couldn’t get you to accept that it wasn’t a good idea for the householder Upāli to rebut the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.

mn56:21.11.pli: Samaṇo hi, bhante, gotamo māyāvī āvaṭṭaniṃ māyaṃ jānāti yāya aññatitthiyānaṃ sāvake āvaṭṭetīti.
mn56:21.11.eng: For the ascetic Gotama is deceitful. He knows a conversion trick, and uses it to convert the disciples of other religions.

mn56:21.12.pli: Āvaṭṭo kho te, bhante, upāli gahapati samaṇena gotamena āvaṭṭaniyā māyāyā”ti.
mn56:21.12.eng: The householder Upāli has been converted by the ascetic Gotama’s conversion trick!”

mn56:21.13.pli: “Aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, tapassi, anavakāso yaṃ upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyya.
mn56:21.13.eng: “It is impossible, Tapassī, it cannot happen that Upāli could become Gotama’s disciple.

mn56:21.14.pli: Ṭhānañca kho etaṃ vijjati yaṃ samaṇo gotamo upālissa gahapatissa sāvakattaṃ upagaccheyyā”ti.
mn56:21.14.eng: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.”

mn56:21.15.pli: Dutiyampi kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:

mn56:21.18.pli: Tatiyampi kho dīghatapassī nigaṇṭho nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:21.18.eng: and a third time, Dīgha Tapassī told the Jain Ñātika

mn56:21.22.pli: “Handa cāhaṃ, tapassi, gacchāmi yāva cāhaṃ sāmaṃyeva jānāmi yadi vā upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato yadi vā no”ti.
mn56:21.22.eng: Well, Tapassī, I’d better go and find out for myself whether or not Upāli has become Gotama’s disciple.”

mn56:22.1.pli: Atha kho nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ yena upālissa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
mn56:22.1.eng: Then the Jain Ñātika went to Upāli’s home together with a large following of Jain ascetics.

mn56:22.2.pli: Addasā kho dovāriko nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn56:22.2.eng: The gatekeeper saw him coming off in the distance

mn56:22.5.pli: Ajjatagge upāli gahapati samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakattaṃ upagato.
mn56:22.5.eng: From now on the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.

mn56:22.6.pli: Āvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ nigaṇṭhīnaṃ, anāvaṭaṃ dvāraṃ bhagavato bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānaṃ.
mn56:22.6.eng: His gate is closed to Jain monks and nuns, and opened for the Buddha’s monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

mn56:22.7.pli: Sace te, bhante, piṇḍakena attho, ettheva tiṭṭha, ettheva te āharissantī”ti.
mn56:22.7.eng: If you require almsfood, wait here, they will bring it to you.”

mn56:22.8.pli: “Tena hi, samma dovārika, yena upāli gahapati tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā upāliṃ gahapatiṃ evaṃ vadehi:
mn56:22.8.eng: “Well then, my good gatekeeper, go to Upāli and say:

mn56:22.9.pli: ‘nigaṇṭho, bhante, nāṭaputto mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhito;
mn56:22.9.eng: ‘Sir, the Jain Ñātika is waiting outside the gates together with a large following of Jain ascetics.

mn56:22.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho dovāriko nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa paṭissutvā yena upāli gahapati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā upāliṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
mn56:22.11.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He went to Upāli and relayed what was said.

mn56:22.12.pli: “nigaṇṭho, bhante, nāṭaputto mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ bahidvārakoṭṭhake ṭhito;

mn56:22.14.pli: “Tena hi, samma dovārika, majjhimāya dvārasālāya āsanāni paññapehī”ti.
mn56:22.14.eng: Upāli said to him, “Well, then, my good gatekeeper, prepare seats in the hall of the middle gate.”

mn56:22.15.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho dovāriko upālissa gahapatissa paṭissutvā majjhimāya dvārasālāya āsanāni paññapetvā yena upāli gahapati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā upāliṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
mn56:22.15.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He did as he was asked, then returned to Upāli and said,

mn56:22.16.eng: “Sir, seats have been prepared in the hall of the middle gate.

mn56:23.1.pli: Atha kho upāli gahapati yena majjhimā dvārasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā yaṃ tattha āsanaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca uttamañca paṇītañca tattha sāmaṃ nisīditvā dovārikaṃ āmantesi:
mn56:23.1.eng: Then Upāli went to the hall of the middle gate, where he sat on the highest and finest seat. He addressed the gatekeeper,

mn56:23.2.pli: “tena hi, samma dovārika, yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ evaṃ vadehi:
mn56:23.2.eng: “Well then, my good gatekeeper, go to the Jain Ñātika and say to him:

mn56:23.4.eng: you may enter if you wish.’”

mn56:23.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho dovāriko upālissa gahapatissa paṭissutvā yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:23.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He went to the Jain Ñātika and relayed what was said.

mn56:23.8.pli: Atha kho nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto mahatiyā nigaṇṭhaparisāya saddhiṃ yena majjhimā dvārasālā tenupasaṅkami.
mn56:23.8.eng: Then the Jain Ñātika went to the hall of the middle gate together with a large following of Jain ascetics.

mn56:24.2.pli: yaṃ sudaṃ pubbe yato passati nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ disvāna tato paccuggantvā yaṃ tattha āsanaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca uttamañca paṇītañca taṃ uttarāsaṅgena sammajjitvā pariggahetvā nisīdāpeti so—
mn56:24.2.eng: Previously, when Upāli saw the Jain Ñātika coming, he would go out to greet him and, having wiped off the highest and finest seat with his upper robe, he would embrace him and sit him down.
mn56:24.2.comm: Pariggahetvā (“embrace”) is used in only one other passage, where it refers to a nurse cradling a baby’s head (AN 5.7:1.9, MN 58:7.6).

mn56:24.3.pli: dāni yaṃ tattha āsanaṃ aggañca seṭṭhañca uttamañca paṇītañca tattha sāmaṃ nisīditvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:24.3.eng: But today, having seated himself on the highest and finest seat, he said to the Jain Ñātika,

mn56:25.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto upāliṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
mn56:25.1.eng: When he said this, the Jain Ñātika said to him:

mn56:25.3.pli: ‘Gacchāmahaṃ, bhante, samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropessāmī’ti gantvā mahatāsi vādasaṅghāṭena paṭimukko āgato.
mn56:25.3.eng: You said: ‘I’ll go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.’ But you come back caught in the vast net of his doctrine.

mn56:25.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, puriso aṇḍahārako gantvā ubbhatehi aṇḍehi āgaccheyya, seyyathā vā pana gahapati puriso akkhikahārako gantvā ubbhatehi akkhīhi āgaccheyya;
mn56:25.4.eng: Suppose a man went to deliver a pair of testicles, but came back castrated. Or they went to deliver eyes, but came back blinded.

mn56:25.5.pli: evameva kho tvaṃ, gahapati, ‘gacchāmahaṃ, bhante, samaṇassa gotamassa vādaṃ āropessāmī’ti gantvā mahatāsi vādasaṅghāṭena paṭimukko āgato.
mn56:25.5.eng: In the same way, you said: ‘I’ll go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.’ But you come back caught in the vast net of his doctrine.

mn56:25.6.pli: Āvaṭṭosi kho tvaṃ, gahapati, samaṇena gotamena āvaṭṭaniyā māyāyā”ti.
mn56:25.6.eng: You’ve been converted by the ascetic Gotama’s conversion trick!”

mn56:26.3.pli: piyā me, bhante, ñātisālohitā imāya āvaṭṭaniyā āvaṭṭeyyuṃ; piyānampi me assa ñātisālohitānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya;
mn56:26.3.eng: If my loved ones—relatives and kin—were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

mn56:26.4.pli: sabbe cepi, bhante, khattiyā imāya āvaṭṭaniyā āvaṭṭeyyuṃ; sabbesānampissa khattiyānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya; sabbe cepi, bhante, brāhmaṇā …pe… vessā …pe… suddā imāya āvaṭṭaniyā āvaṭṭeyyuṃ; sabbesānampissa suddānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya;
mn56:26.4.eng: If all the aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

mn56:26.5.pli: sadevako cepi, bhante, loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā imāya āvaṭṭaniyā āvaṭṭeyyuṃ; sadevakassapissa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti.
mn56:26.5.eng: If the whole world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

mn56:26.6.pli: Tena hi, bhante, upamaṃ te karissāmi.
mn56:26.6.eng: Well then, sir, I shall give you a simile.

mn56:26.7.pli: Upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
mn56:26.7.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

mn56:27.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhante, aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa jiṇṇassa vuḍḍhassa mahallakassa daharā māṇavikā pajāpatī ahosi gabbhinī upavijaññā.
mn56:27.1.eng: Once upon a time there was an old brahmin, elderly and senior. His wife was a young brahmin lady who was pregnant and about to give birth.
mn56:27.1.comm: The age at which girls were considered ready for marriage was sixteen.

mn56:27.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sā māṇavikā taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca,
mn56:27.2.eng: Then she said to the brahmin,

mn56:27.3.pli: ‘gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpakaṃ kiṇitvā ānehi, yo me kumārakassa kīḷāpanako bhavissatī’ti.
mn56:27.3.eng: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’
mn56:27.3.comm: Though the word is not used, this is the dohaḷa, the desire of a (usually pregnant) woman that is as unstoppable as it is irrational. In numerous Jātaka stories as well as across Indian storytelling generally, it serves to send a hero on his journey. For a developed dohaḷa story in the canon, see the legend of Dīghāvu (Kd 10:2.3.1).

mn56:27.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, so brāhmaṇo taṃ māṇavikaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.4.eng: When she said this, the brahmin said to her,

mn56:27.5.eng: ‘Wait, my dear, until you give birth.

mn56:27.6.pli: Sace tvaṃ, bhoti, kumārakaṃ vijāyissasi, tassā te ahaṃ āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpakaṃ kiṇitvā ānessāmi, yo te kumārakassa kīḷāpanako bhavissati.
mn56:27.6.eng: If your child is a boy, I’ll buy you a male monkey,

mn56:27.7.pli: Sace pana tvaṃ, bhoti, kumārikaṃ vijāyissasi, tassā te ahaṃ āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpikaṃ kiṇitvā ānessāmi, yā te kumārikāya kīḷāpanikā bhavissatī’ti.
mn56:27.7.eng: but if it’s a girl, I’ll buy a female monkey.’

mn56:27.9.pli: tatiyampi kho, bhante, sā māṇavikā taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.9.eng: and a third time she said to the brahmin,

mn56:27.10.pli: ‘gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpakaṃ kiṇitvā ānehi, yo me kumārakassa kīḷāpanako bhavissatī’ti.
mn56:27.10.eng: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’

mn56:27.11.pli: Atha kho, bhante, so brāhmaṇo tassā māṇavikāya sāratto paṭibaddhacitto āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpakaṃ kiṇitvā ānetvā taṃ māṇavikaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.11.eng: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, bought a male baby monkey at the market, brought it to her, and said,

mn56:27.12.pli: ‘ayaṃ te, bhoti, āpaṇā makkaṭacchāpako kiṇitvā ānīto, yo te kumārakassa kīḷāpanako bhavissatī’ti.
mn56:27.12.eng: ‘I’ve bought this male baby monkey for you so it can be a playmate for your child.’

mn56:27.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sā māṇavikā taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.13.eng: When he said this, she said to him,

mn56:27.14.pli: ‘gaccha tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imaṃ makkaṭacchāpakaṃ ādāya yena rattapāṇi rajakaputto tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā rattapāṇiṃ rajakaputtaṃ evaṃ vadehi—
mn56:27.14.eng: ‘Go, brahmin, take this monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and say,

mn56:27.15.pli: icchāmahaṃ, samma rattapāṇi, imaṃ makkaṭacchāpakaṃ pītāvalepanaṃ nāma raṅgajātaṃ rajitaṃ ākoṭitapaccākoṭitaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhan’ti.
mn56:27.15.eng: “Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.”’

mn56:27.16.pli: Atha kho, bhante, so brāhmaṇo tassā māṇavikāya sāratto paṭibaddhacitto taṃ makkaṭacchāpakaṃ ādāya yena rattapāṇi rajakaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rattapāṇiṃ rajakaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.16.eng: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, took the monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and said,

mn56:27.17.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, samma rattapāṇi, imaṃ makkaṭacchāpakaṃ pītāvalepanaṃ nāma raṅgajātaṃ rajitaṃ ākoṭitapaccākoṭitaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhan’ti.
mn56:27.17.eng: ‘Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’

mn56:27.18.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, rattapāṇi rajakaputto taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.18.eng: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,

mn56:27.19.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho te, bhante, makkaṭacchāpako raṅgakkhamo hi kho, no ākoṭanakkhamo, no vimajjanakkhamo’ti.
mn56:27.19.eng: ‘Sir, this monkey can endure a dying, but not a pounding or a pressing.’

mn56:27.20.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, bālānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ vādo raṅgakkhamo hi kho bālānaṃ no paṇḍitānaṃ, no anuyogakkhamo, no vimajjanakkhamo.
mn56:27.20.eng: In the same way, the doctrine of the foolish Jains looks fine initially—for fools, not for the astute—but can’t endure being scrutinized or pressed.

mn56:27.21.pli: Atha kho, bhante, so brāhmaṇo aparena samayena navaṃ dussayugaṃ ādāya yena rattapāṇi rajakaputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rattapāṇiṃ rajakaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.21.eng: Then some time later that brahmin took a new pair of garments to Rattapāṇi the dyer and said,

mn56:27.22.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, samma rattapāṇi, imaṃ navaṃ dussayugaṃ pītāvalepanaṃ nāma raṅgajātaṃ rajitaṃ ākoṭitapaccākoṭitaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhan’ti.
mn56:27.22.eng: ‘Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this new pair of garments dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’

mn56:27.23.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, rattapāṇi rajakaputto taṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:27.23.eng: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,

mn56:27.24.pli: ‘idaṃ kho te, bhante, navaṃ dussayugaṃ raṅgakkhamañceva ākoṭanakkhamañca vimajjanakkhamañcā’ti.
mn56:27.24.eng: ‘Sir, this pair of garments can endure a dying, a pounding, and a pressing.’

mn56:27.25.pli: Evameva kho, bhante, tassa bhagavato vādo arahato sammāsambuddhassa raṅgakkhamo ceva paṇḍitānaṃ no bālānaṃ, anuyogakkhamo ca vimajjanakkhamo cā”ti.
mn56:27.25.eng: In the same way, the doctrine of the Buddha looks fine initially—for the astute, not for fools—and it can endure being scrutinized and pressed.”

mn56:28.1.eng: “Householder, the king and his retinue know you as

mn56:28.2.eng: a disciple of the Jain Ñātika.

mn56:28.3.eng: Whose disciple should we remember you as?”

mn56:29.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, upāli gahapati uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn56:29.1.eng: When he had spoken, the householder Upāli got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms in the direction of the Buddha, and said to the Jain Ñātika,

mn56:29.2.eng: “Well then, sir, hear whose disciple I am:

mn56:29.3.eng: The attentive one, free of delusion,

mn56:29.4.eng: with hard-heartedness dissolved, victor in battle;
mn56:29.4.comm: Read khīla as khila, a reference to the five kinds of hard-heartedness. For similar idioms see Snp 4.16:19.2 and SN 8.8:8.2 = Thag 21.1:34.2.

mn56:29.6.eng: with the virtue of an elder and the wisdom of a saint,

mn56:29.7.eng: immaculate in the midst of it all:
mn56:29.7.comm: “In the midst of it all” is vessantara, as in the famous Jātaka of that name (Ja 547). MA 133 here has 安隱, where 隱 represents antara, and 安 may be sama. Vessa in the sense of “all” is rare in Pali.

mn56:29.8.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.9.eng: He has no indecision, he’s content,

mn56:29.10.eng: joyful, he has spat out the world’s bait;

mn56:29.11.eng: he has completed the ascetic’s task as a man,

mn56:29.12.eng: a man who bears his final body;

mn56:29.14.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.15.eng: He’s free of doubt, he’s skillful,

mn56:29.16.eng: he’s a trainer, an excellent charioteer;

mn56:29.19.eng: he has cut off conceit, he’s a hero:

mn56:29.20.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.23.eng: he is the maker of sanctuary, knowledgeable,

mn56:29.25.eng: he has slipped his chains and is liberated:

mn56:29.26.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.28.eng: he’s ended the fetters and is liberated;

mn56:29.29.eng: he’s skilled in debate and cleansed,

mn56:29.32.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.33.eng: He is the seventh seer, free of deceit,
mn56:29.33.comm: The idea of the seven sages, long proverbial in Vedic culture, was adapted for Gotama in DN 14, where he is the seventh recorded Buddha. Readings of this phrase in various texts and commentaries also allow the sense, “best of seers”.

mn56:29.34.eng: with three knowledges, he has attained to divinity,

mn56:29.35.eng: he has bathed, he knows philology,
mn56:29.35.comm: The terms here are all Brahmanical, so we should take padaka in the usual sense of “philology” as in eg. MN 91:2.1.

mn56:29.36.eng: he’s tranquil, he understands what is known;

mn56:29.37.eng: he is Sakka the Able, Purindada the Firstgiver:
mn56:29.37.comm: Sakka (śakra) was originally an epithet of Indra, the “able one”. | Purandara (“Fortbreaker”) is another epithet (eg. Rig Veda 1.102.7). The Buddha reforms it to Purindada (“Firstgiver”) at SN 11.12:2.1. But Indra’s generosity is long renowned, eg. Rig Veda 1.10.6c: “He is the able one, and he will be able for us—Indra who distributes the goods” (sa śakra uta naḥ śakad indro vasu dayamānaḥ).

mn56:29.38.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.40.eng: he has attained the goal and explains it;

mn56:29.42.eng: neither leaning forward nor pulling back,
mn56:29.42.comm: These terms refer to samādhi at SN 1.38:8.2 and AN 9.37:8.2.

mn56:29.44.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.45.comm: At Thig 14.1:14.1 samuggata refers to a lily rising above the waters; at SN 10.7:10.2 to rising above suffering.

mn56:29.46.eng: no inner thoughts arising, he is pure,
mn56:29.46.comm: See Ud 4.1:23.2, where anu(g)gata refers to thoughts that “arise” in the mind.

mn56:29.47.comm: Readings are unclear; I follow Thai appabhītassa.

mn56:29.48.eng: secluded, he has reached the peak,

mn56:29.49.eng: crossed over, he helps others across:

mn56:29.50.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.51.eng: He’s peaceful, his wisdom is vast,

mn56:29.52.eng: with great wisdom, he’s free of greed;

mn56:29.53.eng: he is the Realized One, the Holy One,

mn56:29.56.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.

mn56:29.57.eng: He has cut off craving and is awakened,

mn56:29.59.eng: a mighty spirit worthy of offerings,
mn56:29.59.comm: The Chinese here evidently reads akkha (“eye”), but in the context of offerings I think yakkha (“spirit”) fits better. Conversion legends of yakkhas tell how the cruel offerings of sacrifice are replaced with the harmless offerings to the Buddha. Perhaps it was later adjusted to akkha as the yakkha developed a poor reputation in later Buddhism.

mn56:29.61.eng: grand, he has reached the peak of glory:

mn56:29.62.eng: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.”

mn56:30.1.pli: “Kadā saññūḷhā pana te, gahapati, ime samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇā”ti?
mn56:30.1.eng: “But when did you compose these praises of the ascetic Gotama’s beautiful qualities, householder?”
mn56:30.1.comm: “When did you compose” is also at DN 21:1.6.4.

mn56:30.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhante, nānāpupphānaṃ mahāpuppharāsi, tamenaṃ dakkho mālākāro vā mālākārantevāsī vā vicittaṃ mālaṃ gantheyya;
mn56:30.2.eng: “Sir, suppose there was a large heap of many different flowers. A deft garland-maker or their apprentice could tie them into a colorful garland.

mn56:30.3.pli: evameva kho, bhante, so bhagavā anekavaṇṇo anekasatavaṇṇo.
mn56:30.3.eng: In the same way, the Buddha has many beautiful qualities to praise, many hundreds of such qualities.
mn56:30.3.comm: Upāli is playing on the dual senses of vaṇṇa as both “praise” and “beauty”. In doing so, he implicitly answers Mahāvīra’s question: he is adept at poetic improvisation (paṭibhāna).

mn56:30.4.pli: Ko hi, bhante, vaṇṇārahassa vaṇṇaṃ na karissatī”ti?
mn56:30.4.eng: Who, sir, would not praise the praiseworthy?”

mn56:31.1.pli: Atha kho nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa bhagavato sakkāraṃ asahamānassa tattheva uṇhaṃ lohitaṃ mukhato uggacchīti.
mn56:31.1.eng: Unable to bear this honor paid to the Buddha, the Jain Ñātika spewed hot blood from his mouth there and then.
mn56:31.1.comm: The Pali commentary says this was the cause of his death in Pāvā soon after, which supports the contention that Pāvā is Pāvārika. The Jain Kalpasūtra, however, tells a very different story, of a triumphant leader who, having lived a long and exemplary life, mindfully departed this world in honor and dignity, to the consternation of the gods.
